thread.title: United Airlines fined $10,000 for Troy Newman visa breach, but border security questions remain
thread.title_full: United Airlines fined $10,000 for Troy Newman visa breach, but border security questions remain

title: United Airlines fined $10,000 for Troy Newman visa breach, but border security questions remain
text:
Return to video Video settings Please Log in to update your video settings

Calais 'jungle' camp migrant numbers double to 6000
Replay video Return to video Video settings Please Log in to update your video settings
Troy Newman fury at flight check-in RAW VISION: Australia-bound US anti-abortion campaigner uploaded this video to his Facebook page, urging followers to "make it go viral" after last-minute Australian government intervention prevented him from boarding a flight in Denver.
PT1M31S 620 349 Autoplay On Off Video feedback Video settings Anti-abortion campaigner deported United Airlines has been slapped with a $10,000 fine for letting controversial US anti-abortion campaigner Troy Newman fly to Australia without a visa, but questions remain over how he slipped through the net in a heightened border control climate.
The fine was served on the airline after Mr Newman boarded a flight in Los Angeles and flew to Melbourne earlier this month, despite the Department of Immigration cancelling his visa on character grounds and warnings being issued on the Movement Alert List.
Troy Newman flew to Australia despite not being issued a visa. Photo: Charlie Riedel
A department spokesman confirmed to Fairfax Media that United Airlines had been fined $10,000 for allowing Mr Newman to board "despite communication from the department that he was not allowed to do so".
Advertisement It is understood the visa cancellation meant Mr Newman was placed on the Movement Alert List, and the onus was on the airline to ensure he did not board the plane.
The list contains the details of more than 700,000 people who pose a possible security or health risk, or owe money to the Commonwealth.
United Airlines has been slapped with a $10,000 fine.
It is considered an integral part of Australia's national security and border control strategy, particularly as passenger movements rise.
A spokesperson for the airline said: "United takes this matter seriously and is currently working closely with the Australian and US authorities to investigate how this occurred. United is also conducting a separate internal review."
Mr Dutton had instructed the department to investigate how Mr Newman was able to board the flight despite red flags being raised in the Movement Alert List system.
In 2011 then-Australian Security Intelligence Organisation head David Irvine described the list as "very fallible" because there were "people who perhaps should be on it who aren't."
An Australian National Audit Office report in 2009 found the database lacked strategic planning and contained poor quality data which "compromised the system's effectiveness".
It made five recommendations. A follow up report last year found the department had failed to fully implement three of them, even after claiming the measures were wholly or substantially in place.
That report made four new recommendations, which the department this week said were "in the progress of being implemented".
Mr Newman was detained by the Australian Border Force at the airport before being held at Melbourne's Maribyrnong detention centre overnight, then deported.
The High Court threw out an emergency bid by Mr Newman to stop authorities removing him from Australia.
Lawyers for Immigration Minister Peter Dutton and Mr Newman were scheduled to reappear in court on October 30, to determine if the department was legally entitled to cancel Mr Newman's visa.
